text:
Does anyone have insight into how the Canadian market compares to US for content writing?

I'm Canadian and all of my clients right now are in the US but I'm reaching out to some Canadian brands and would like to know if I should be adjusting my rates rather than just converting to CAD.

Appreciate any info anyone can share. Feel free to DM too if you'd rather

text: Agree with <@U032YNAE4FP>. I would also add just general confidence in yourself and the service you offer. The more you believe in your own expertise and the more you really believe you can deliver value to the customer the easier it is to sell. It took me a looong while to really build my confidence and believe in my own value, but now that I have it, I see it makes a HUGE difference.

elements.text: Agree with

. I would also add just general confidence in yourself and the service you offer. The more you believe in your own expertise and the more you really believe you can deliver value to the customer the easier it is to sell. It took me a looong while to really build my confidence and believe in my own value, but now that I have it, I see it makes a HUGE difference.

text: <@U034NCQDL4C> that's so true! I guess after you do enough Discovery calls and client facing meetings you tend to feel that confidence building as a result. Prospects sense your confidence and belief and then tend to buy into you more as well as what you offer. It's a bit of an upward cycle in that respect. :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: that's so true! I guess after you do enough Discovery calls and client facing meetings you tend to feel that confidence building as a result. text: I'm curious about this too--fellow Canadian here. I've only worked with US clients so far, so sorry for not being able to help!

elements.text: I'm curious about this too--fellow Canadian here. I've only worked with US clients so far, so sorry for not being able to help!

text:
Hey <@U0320CENNGK>,

I just finished a conversation with another Superpath slack member and what I gathered was Canadian businesses might have lower budgets as in one freelancer's experience they tend to pay 10-20% less before conversion.

So if a US business would pay $500 USD for a project, a Canadian business might pay $400 to $450 CAD for the same project.

elements.text: Hey

,

I just finished a conversation with another Superpath slack member and what I gathered was Canadian businesses might have lower budgets as in one freelancer's experience they tend to pay 10-20% less before conversion.

So if a US business would pay $500 USD for a project, a Canadian business might pay $400 to $450 CAD for the same project.

text: Let's talk benefits! I was just offered a full-time position and was excited about the prospect...until I received the offer letter. They offered only 10 days of PTO/sick (combined) for the year and it was also on an accrual basis. While the job IS remote (which I appreciate), and I could most likely negotiate more...I was shocked by the 10 days. Is this normal in the market today? I have been freelancing for so long and looking to transition into a full-time position, but this threw me for a loop. I hate the term "work/life" balance, but how is this any kind of balance?

elements.text: Let's talk benefits! I was just offered a full-time position and was excited about the prospect...until I received the offer letter. I have been freelancing for so long and looking to transition into a full-time position, but this threw me for a loop. I hate the term "work/life" balance, but how is this any kind of balance?

text: it's not enough time. esp if it's combined PTO/sick

elements.text: it's not enough time. esp if it's combined PTO/sick

text: what about holidays?

elements.text: what about holidays?

text: i know some remote companies flex holidays, i.e. you get 10 paid holidays but can use them whenever you want. e.g. work memorial day and use the day off some other time. i don't love that either bc you end being forced to work when everyone else is off

elements.text: i know some remote companies flex holidays, i.e. you get 10 paid holidays but can use them whenever you want. e.g. work memorial day and use the day off some other time. i don't love that either bc you end being forced to work when everyone else is off

text: it actually says "10 days sick/personal days given on an actual basis, AFTER the first year with the company" Which is worse.

elements.text: it actually says "10 days sick/personal days given on an actual basis, AFTER the first year with the company" Which is worse.

text: I think I had that many days off back in 2008 when I worked in the casino, and I remember saying to myself "NEVER AGAIN." accrual PTO days are so stressful.

elements.text: I think I had that many days off back in 2008 when I worked in the casino, and I remember saying to myself "NEVER AGAIN." accrual PTO days are so stressful.

text: I’m in shock. My perception is that unlimited PTO (which includes sick leave) is the moving toward the norm. And I’m hearing frequently of companies turning 3-day holiday weekends into 4 days (MLK, presidents, etc)

elements.text: I’m in shock. My perception is that unlimited PTO (which includes sick leave) is the moving toward the norm. And I’m hearing frequently of companies turning 3-day holiday weekends into 4 days (MLK, presidents, etc)

text:
That is NOT the norm and you are worth so much more. This is a candidate’s market, so make sure to negotiate. 

For reference, I get five days of sick leave, a 10 day Covid sick bank (to use for myself or if my dependents are sick), 25 days PTO, 12 holidays, one floating holiday and one volunteer day.

elements.text:

text:
I agree that Canadian companies will generally be more price sensitive / have unrealistic budget expectations. But there are signals that can help you optimize for higher paying Canadian clients, including:
• Recent VC funding
• American leadership, especially head of marketing
• Investment in marketing overall

elements.text: I agree that Canadian companies will generally be more price sensitive / have unrealistic budget expectations. But there are signals that can help you optimize for higher paying Canadian clients, including:
Recent VC funding
American leadership, especially head of marketing
Investment in marketing overall

text: <@U02A8UR3Z60> this makes me feel so much better - putting it into perspective like this. I'm honestly not sure I want to even negotiate with a company that offers just 10 days. It doesn't give me the warm and fuzzy feelings when it comes to employee worth/wellbeing. I already had to negotiate my pay (which is already low.) AND there is a clause in there that I have to be available for 40 hours a week + "emergencies."

text: NP! Those 3 factors were present at companies where I had the highest content budget to spend on freelancers and I was given the directive to work with “the best” writers in our niche regardless of cost. Having a recognizable niche (and making that findable via search) helps in terms of demanding the highest prices as well. I ended up Googling “best [our niche] freelancer writer” etc and I think 3/4 writers I ended up working with were American vs Canadian.

10 days is absolutely not enough and if you're already feeling unsure, I would listen to your gut.

text: I have unlimited PTO, and had it at my last job as well. It's definitely moving toward the norm, and it's a candidate's market right now, so it's totally fair for you to negotiate for more days off. I'd ask for 14 vacation and 7 for sick leave, with the hope of a counter offer of 14 total. Another option is to calculate the missed opportunity cost and negotiate that as increased salary so you pay yourself for additional time off beyond their final offer.

elements.text: I have unlimited PTO, and had it at my last job as well. It's definitely moving toward the norm, and it's a candidate's market right now, so it's totally fair for you to negotiate for more days off. I'd ask for 14 vacation and 7 for sick leave, with the hope of a counter offer of 14 total. Another option is to calculate the missed opportunity cost and negotiate that as increased salary so you pay yourself for additional time off beyond their final offer.

text: That's really insane! I hope you can find a good job that exactly fits what you need. I think this is a great barrier for anyone who works as a freelancer to come back to a full-time position. After 5 years of remote working, now I prefer fractional work as my future way. Working for a company full-time with these motivation breakers is too hard. :disappointed:

text:
Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonymous questions. 

Career stage: mid (4-7 years of experience)

"When you're choosing a new job, how important is the product — the complexity, the innovation, the vision, the roadmap — to your decision? 

I've recently been offered a new job with a very exciting product, though I understand it's a much more chaotic startup environment with a less developed sales pipeline. My current job (2 years and counting) is very pleasant and the company is growing, but I'm getting a little bored. 

For additional context, new job would be a cutting edge data product, current job is a great marketing product. Both B2B SaaS. Great problem to have, huh?"
